--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:isAttached:LoadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary_isAttached</a> - When
--   <tt>true</tt>, the SSL/TLS certificate is attached to the Lightsail
--   load balancer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:LoadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary_name</a> - The name of the
--   SSL/TLS certificate.
newLoadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary :: LoadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary

-- | When <tt>true</tt>, the SSL/TLS certificate is attached to the
--   Lightsail load balancer.
loadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary_isAttached :: Lens' LoadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary (Maybe Bool)

-- | The name of the SSL/TLS certificate.
loadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary_name :: Lens' LoadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary (Maybe Text)

module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.LogEvent

-- | Describes a database log event.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newLogEvent</a> smart constructor.
data LogEvent
LogEvent' :: Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> LogEvent

-- | The timestamp when the database log event was created.
[$sel:createdAt:LogEvent'] :: LogEvent -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The message of the database log event.
[$sel:message:LogEvent'] :: LogEvent -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>LogEvent</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:LogEvent'</a>, <a>logEvent_createdAt</a> - The
--   timestamp when the database log event was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:message:LogEvent'</a>, <a>logEvent_message</a> - The message
--   of the database log event.
newLogEvent :: LogEvent

-- | The timestamp when the database log event was created.
logEvent_createdAt :: Lens' LogEvent (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The message of the database log event.
logEvent_message :: Lens' LogEvent (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.LogEvent.LogEvent
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.LogEvent.LogEvent
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.LogEvent.LogEvent
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.LogEvent.LogEvent

module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.MetricDatapoint

-- | Describes the metric data point.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newMetricDatapoint</a> smart constructor.
data MetricDatapoint
MetricDatapoint' :: Maybe Double -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Double -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe MetricUnit -> MetricDatapoint

-- | The sample count.
[$sel:sampleCount:MetricDatapoint'] :: MetricDatapoint -> Maybe Double

-- | The maximum.
[$sel:maximum:MetricDatapoint'] :: MetricDatapoint -> Maybe Double

-- | The average.
[$sel:average:MetricDatapoint'] :: MetricDatapoint -> Maybe Double

-- | The minimum.
[$sel:minimum:MetricDatapoint'] :: MetricDatapoint -> Maybe Double

-- | The sum.
[$sel:sum:MetricDatapoint'] :: MetricDatapoint -> Maybe Double

-- | The timestamp (e.g., <tt>1479816991.349</tt>).
[$sel:timestamp:MetricDatapoint'] :: MetricDatapoint -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The unit.
[$sel:unit:MetricDatapoint'] :: MetricDatapoint -> Maybe MetricUnit

-- | Create a value of <a>MetricDatapoint</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:sampleCount:MetricDatapoint'</a>,
--   <a>metricDatapoint_sampleCount</a> - The sample count.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maximum:MetricDatapoint'</a>, <a>metricDatapoint_maximum</a> -
--   The maximum.
--   
--   <a>$sel:average:MetricDatapoint'</a>, <a>metricDatapoint_average</a> -
--   The average.
--   
--   <a>$sel:minimum:MetricDatapoint'</a>, <a>metricDatapoint_minimum</a> -
--   The minimum.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sum:MetricDatapoint'</a>, <a>metricDatapoint_sum</a> - The
--   sum.
--   
--   <a>$sel:timestamp:MetricDatapoint'</a>,
--   <a>metricDatapoint_timestamp</a> - The timestamp (e.g.,
--   <tt>1479816991.349</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:unit:MetricDatapoint'</a>, <a>metricDatapoint_unit</a> - The
--   unit.
newMetricDatapoint :: MetricDatapoint

-- | The sample count.
metricDatapoint_sampleCount :: Lens' MetricDatapoint (Maybe Double)

-- | The maximum.
metricDatapoint_maximum :: Lens' MetricDatapoint (Maybe Double)

-- | The average.
metricDatapoint_average :: Lens' MetricDatapoint (Maybe Double)

-- | The minimum.
metricDatapoint_minimum :: Lens' MetricDatapoint (Maybe Double)

-- | The sum.
metricDatapoint_sum :: Lens' MetricDatapoint (Maybe Double)

-- | The timestamp (e.g., <tt>1479816991.349</tt>).
metricDatapoint_timestamp :: Lens' MetricDatapoint (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The unit.
metricDatapoint_unit :: Lens' MetricDatapoint (Maybe MetricUnit)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.MetricDatapoint.MetricDatapoint
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.MetricDatapoint.MetricDatapoint
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.MetricDatapoint.MetricDatapoint
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.MetricDatapoint.MetricDatapoint
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.MetricDatapoint.MetricDatapoint
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.MetricDatapoint.MetricDatapoint
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.MetricDatapoint.MetricDatapoint


module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.MonthlyTransfer

-- | Describes the monthly data transfer in and out of your virtual private
--   server (or <i>instance</i>).
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newMonthlyTransfer</a> smart constructor.
data MonthlyTransfer
MonthlyTransfer' :: Maybe Int -> MonthlyTransfer

-- | The amount allocated per month (in GB).
[$sel:gbPerMonthAllocated:MonthlyTransfer'] :: MonthlyTransfer -> Maybe Int

-- | Create a value of <a>MonthlyTransfer</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:gbPerMonthAllocated:MonthlyTransfer'</a>,
--   <a>monthlyTransfer_gbPerMonthAllocated</a> - The amount allocated per
--   month (in GB).
newMonthlyTransfer :: MonthlyTransfer

-- | The amount allocated per month (in GB).
monthlyTransfer_gbPerMonthAllocated :: Lens' MonthlyTransfer (Maybe Int)

module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PasswordData

-- | The password data for the Windows Server-based instance, including the
--   ciphertext and the key pair name.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPasswordData</a> smart constructor.
data PasswordData
PasswordData' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> PasswordData

-- | The name of the key pair that you used when creating your instance. If
--   no key pair name was specified when creating the instance, Lightsail
--   uses the default key pair (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>).
--   
--   If you are using a custom key pair, you need to use your own means of
--   decrypting your password using the <tt>ciphertext</tt>. Lightsail
--   creates the ciphertext by encrypting your password with the public key
--   part of this key pair.
[$sel:keyPairName:PasswordData'] :: PasswordData -> Maybe Text

-- | The encrypted password. Ciphertext will be an empty string if access
--   to your new instance is not ready yet. When you create an instance, it
--   can take up to 15 minutes for the instance to be ready.
--   
--   If you use the default key pair (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>),
--   the decrypted password will be available in the password field.
--   
--   If you are using a custom key pair, you need to use your own means of
--   decryption.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original ciphertext value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
[$sel:ciphertext:PasswordData'] :: PasswordData -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>PasswordData</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:keyPairName:PasswordData'</a>, <a>passwordData_keyPairName</a>
--   - The name of the key pair that you used when creating your instance.
--   If no key pair name was specified when creating the instance,
--   Lightsail uses the default key pair
--   (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>).
--   
--   If you are using a custom key pair, you need to use your own means of
--   decrypting your password using the <tt>ciphertext</tt>. Lightsail
--   creates the ciphertext by encrypting your password with the public key
--   part of this key pair.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ciphertext:PasswordData'</a>, <a>passwordData_ciphertext</a> -
--   The encrypted password. Ciphertext will be an empty string if access
--   to your new instance is not ready yet. When you create an instance, it
--   can take up to 15 minutes for the instance to be ready.
--   
--   If you use the default key pair (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>),
--   the decrypted password will be available in the password field.
--   
--   If you are using a custom key pair, you need to use your own means of
--   decryption.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original ciphertext value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
newPasswordData :: PasswordData

-- | The name of the key pair that you used when creating your instance. If
--   no key pair name was specified when creating the instance, Lightsail
--   uses the default key pair (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>).
--   
--   If you are using a custom key pair, you need to use your own means of
--   decrypting your password using the <tt>ciphertext</tt>. Lightsail
--   creates the ciphertext by encrypting your password with the public key
--   part of this key pair.
passwordData_keyPairName :: Lens' PasswordData (Maybe Text)

-- | The encrypted password. Ciphertext will be an empty string if access
--   to your new instance is not ready yet. When you create an instance, it
--   can take up to 15 minutes for the instance to be ready.
--   
--   If you use the default key pair (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>),
--   the decrypted password will be available in the password field.
--   
--   If you are using a custom key pair, you need to use your own means of
--   decryption.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original ciphertext value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
passwordData_ciphertext :: Lens' PasswordData (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PasswordData.PasswordData
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PasswordData.PasswordData
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PasswordData.PasswordData
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PasswordData.PasswordData
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PasswordData.PasswordData
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PasswordData.PasswordData
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PasswordData.PasswordData


module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceAccessDetails

-- | The parameters for gaining temporary access to one of your Amazon
--   Lightsail instances.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceAccessDetails</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceAccessDetails
InstanceAccessDetails' :: Maybe [HostKeyAttributes] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe InstanceAccessProtocol -> Maybe PasswordData -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> InstanceAccessDetails

-- | Describes the public SSH host keys or the RDP certificate.
[$sel:hostKeys:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe [HostKeyAttributes]

-- | For SSH access, the public key to use when accessing your instance For
--   OpenSSH clients (e.g., command line SSH), you should save this value
--   to <tt>tempkey-cert.pub</tt>.
[$sel:certKey:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | The public IP address of the Amazon Lightsail instance.
[$sel:ipAddress:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | For SSH access, the temporary private key. For OpenSSH clients (e.g.,
--   command line SSH), you should save this value to <tt>tempkey</tt>).
[$sel:privateKey:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | For SSH access, the date on which the temporary keys expire.
[$sel:expiresAt:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The user name to use when logging in to the Amazon Lightsail instance.
[$sel:username:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | The protocol for these Amazon Lightsail instance access details.
[$sel:protocol:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe InstanceAccessProtocol

-- | For a Windows Server-based instance, an object with the data you can
--   use to retrieve your password. This is only needed if
--   <tt>password</tt> is empty and the instance is not new (and therefore
--   the password is not ready yet). When you create an instance, it can
--   take up to 15 minutes for the instance to be ready.
[$sel:passwordData:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe PasswordData

-- | For RDP access, the password for your Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   Password will be an empty string if the password for your new instance
--   is not ready yet. When you create an instance, it can take up to 15
--   minutes for the instance to be ready.
--   
--   If you create an instance using any key pair other than the default
--   (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>), <tt>password</tt> will always be
--   an empty string.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original password value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
[$sel:password:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of this Amazon Lightsail instance.
[$sel:instanceName:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceAccessDetails</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostKeys:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_hostKeys</a> - Describes the public SSH host
--   keys or the RDP certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:certKey:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_certKey</a> - For SSH access, the public key
--   to use when accessing your instance For OpenSSH clients (e.g., command
--   line SSH), you should save this value to <tt>tempkey-cert.pub</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddress:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_ipAddress</a> - The public IP address of the
--   Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:privateKey:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_privateKey</a> - For SSH access, the
--   temporary private key. For OpenSSH clients (e.g., command line SSH),
--   you should save this value to <tt>tempkey</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:expiresAt:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_expiresAt</a> - For SSH access, the date on
--   which the temporary keys expire.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_username</a> - The user name to use when
--   logging in to the Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_protocol</a> - The protocol for these Amazon
--   Lightsail instance access details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:passwordData:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_passwordData</a> - For a Windows Server-based
--   instance, an object with the data you can use to retrieve your
--   password. This is only needed if <tt>password</tt> is empty and the
--   instance is not new (and therefore the password is not ready yet).
--   When you create an instance, it can take up to 15 minutes for the
--   instance to be ready.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_password</a> - For RDP access, the password
--   for your Amazon Lightsail instance. Password will be an empty string
--   if the password for your new instance is not ready yet. When you
--   create an instance, it can take up to 15 minutes for the instance to
--   be ready.
--   
--   If you create an instance using any key pair other than the default
--   (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>), <tt>password</tt> will always be
--   an empty string.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original password value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceName:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_instanceName</a> - The name of this Amazon
--   Lightsail instance.
newInstanceAccessDetails :: InstanceAccessDetails

-- | Describes the public SSH host keys or the RDP certificate.
instanceAccessDetails_hostKeys :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe [HostKeyAttributes])

-- | For SSH access, the public key to use when accessing your instance For
--   OpenSSH clients (e.g., command line SSH), you should save this value
--   to <tt>tempkey-cert.pub</tt>.
instanceAccessDetails_certKey :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | The public IP address of the Amazon Lightsail instance.
instanceAccessDetails_ipAddress :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | For SSH access, the temporary private key. For OpenSSH clients (e.g.,
--   command line SSH), you should save this value to <tt>tempkey</tt>).
instanceAccessDetails_privateKey :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | For SSH access, the date on which the temporary keys expire.
instanceAccessDetails_expiresAt :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The user name to use when logging in to the Amazon Lightsail instance.
instanceAccessDetails_username :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol for these Amazon Lightsail instance access details.
instanceAccessDetails_protocol :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe InstanceAccessProtocol)

-- | For a Windows Server-based instance, an object with the data you can
--   use to retrieve your password. This is only needed if
--   <tt>password</tt> is empty and the instance is not new (and therefore
--   the password is not ready yet). When you create an instance, it can
--   take up to 15 minutes for the instance to be ready.
instanceAccessDetails_passwordData :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe PasswordData)

-- | For RDP access, the password for your Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   Password will be an empty string if the password for your new instance
--   is not ready yet. When you create an instance, it can take up to 15
--   minutes for the instance to be ready.
--   
--   If you create an instance using any key pair other than the default
--   (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>), <tt>password</tt> will always be
--   an empty string.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original password value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
instanceAccessDetails_password :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of this Amazon Lightsail instance.
instanceAccessDetails_instanceName :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceAccessDetails.InstanceAccessDetails
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceAccessDetails.InstanceAccessDetails
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceAccessDetails.InstanceAccessDetails
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceAccessDetails.InstanceAccessDetails
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceAccessDetails.InstanceAccessDetails
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceAccessDetails.InstanceAccessDetails
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceAccessDetails.InstanceAccessDetails


module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PendingMaintenanceAction

--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPendingMaintenanceAction</a> smart constructor.

[$sel:action:PendingMaintenanceAction'] :: PendingMaintenanceAction -> Maybe Text

[$sel:description:PendingMaintenanceAction'] :: PendingMaintenanceAction -> Maybe Text

--   of the pending database maintenance action.

[$sel:engineVersion:PendingModifiedRelationalDatabaseValues'] :: PendingModifiedRelationalDatabaseValues -> Maybe Text

module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortInfo

-- | Describes information about ports for an Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstancePortInfo</a> smart constructor.
data InstancePortInfo
InstancePortInfo' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe AccessDirection -> Maybe PortAccessType -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> InstancePortInfo

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:fromPort:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe Int

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:cidrs:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The common name of the port information.
[$sel:commonName:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:protocol:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe NetworkProtocol

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
[$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The access direction (<tt>inbound</tt> or <tt>outbound</tt>).
--   
--   Lightsail currently supports only <tt>inbound</tt> access direction.
[$sel:accessDirection:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe AccessDirection

-- | The type of access (<tt>Public</tt> or <tt>Private</tt>).
[$sel:accessType:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe PortAccessType

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:toPort:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe Int

-- | The location from which access is allowed. For example, <tt>Anywhere
--   (0.0.0.0/0)</tt>, or <tt>Custom</tt> if a specific IP address or range
--   of IP addresses is allowed.
[$sel:accessFrom:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>InstancePortInfo</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_fromPort</a> - The first port in a range of open
--   ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:InstancePortInfo'</a>, <a>instancePortInfo_cidrs</a> -
--   The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:commonName:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_commonName</a> - The common name of the port
--   information.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_protocol</a> - The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_cidrListAliases</a> - An alias that defines access
--   for a preconfigured range of IP addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_ipv6Cidrs</a> - The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6
--   addresses (in CIDR notation) that are allowed to connect to an
--   instance through the ports, and the protocol. Only devices with an
--   IPv6 address can connect to an instance through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4
--   should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessDirection:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_accessDirection</a> - The access direction
--   (<tt>inbound</tt> or <tt>outbound</tt>).
--   
--   Lightsail currently supports only <tt>inbound</tt> access direction.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessType:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_accessType</a> - The type of access
--   (<tt>Public</tt> or <tt>Private</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:InstancePortInfo'</a>, <a>instancePortInfo_toPort</a> -
--   The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessFrom:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_accessFrom</a> - The location from which access is
--   allowed. For example, <tt>Anywhere (0.0.0.0/0)</tt>, or
--   <tt>Custom</tt> if a specific IP address or range of IP addresses is
--   allowed.
newInstancePortInfo :: InstancePortInfo

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
instancePortInfo_fromPort :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe Int)

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
instancePortInfo_cidrs :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The common name of the port information.
instancePortInfo_commonName :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
instancePortInfo_protocol :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe NetworkProtocol)

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
instancePortInfo_cidrListAliases :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
instancePortInfo_ipv6Cidrs :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The access direction (<tt>inbound</tt> or <tt>outbound</tt>).
--   
--   Lightsail currently supports only <tt>inbound</tt> access direction.
instancePortInfo_accessDirection :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe AccessDirection)

-- | The type of access (<tt>Public</tt> or <tt>Private</tt>).
instancePortInfo_accessType :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe PortAccessType)

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
instancePortInfo_toPort :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe Int)

-- | The location from which access is allowed. For example, <tt>Anywhere
--   (0.0.0.0/0)</tt>, or <tt>Custom</tt> if a specific IP address or range
--   of IP addresses is allowed.
instancePortInfo_accessFrom :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortInfo.InstancePortInfo
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortInfo.InstancePortInfo
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortInfo.InstancePortInfo
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortInfo.InstancePortInfo
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortInfo.InstancePortInfo
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortInfo.InstancePortInfo
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortInfo.InstancePortInfo


module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceNetworking

-- | Describes monthly data transfer rates and port information for an
--   instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceNetworking</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceNetworking
InstanceNetworking' :: Maybe MonthlyTransfer -> Maybe [InstancePortInfo] -> InstanceNetworking

-- | The amount of data in GB allocated for monthly data transfers.
[$sel:monthlyTransfer:InstanceNetworking'] :: InstanceNetworking -> Maybe MonthlyTransfer

-- | An array of key-value pairs containing information about the ports on
--   the instance.
[$sel:ports:InstanceNetworking'] :: InstanceNetworking -> Maybe [InstancePortInfo]

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceNetworking</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:monthlyTransfer:InstanceNetworking'</a>,
--   <a>instanceNetworking_monthlyTransfer</a> - The amount of data in GB
--   allocated for monthly data transfers.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ports:InstanceNetworking'</a>, <a>instanceNetworking_ports</a>
--   - An array of key-value pairs containing information about the ports
--   on the instance.
newInstanceNetworking :: InstanceNetworking

-- | The amount of data in GB allocated for monthly data transfers.
instanceNetworking_monthlyTransfer :: Lens' InstanceNetworking (Maybe MonthlyTransfer)

-- | An array of key-value pairs containing information about the ports on
--   the instance.
instanceNetworking_ports :: Lens' InstanceNetworking (Maybe [InstancePortInfo])
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceNetworking.InstanceNetworking
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceNetworking.InstanceNetworking
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceNetworking.InstanceNetworking
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceNetworking.InstanceNetworking
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceNetworking.InstanceNetworking
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceNetworking.InstanceNetworking
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceNetworking.InstanceNetworking


module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfo

-- | Describes ports to open on an instance, the IP addresses allowed to
--   connect to the instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPortInfo</a> smart constructor.
data PortInfo
PortInfo' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Int -> PortInfo

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:fromPort:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe Int

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   Examples:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To allow the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt> or <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To allow the IP addresses <tt>192.0.2.0</tt> to
--   <tt>192.0.2.255</tt>, specify <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:cidrs:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:protocol:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe NetworkProtocol

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
[$sel:cidrListAliases:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:ipv6Cidrs:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:toPort:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe Int

-- | Create a value of <a>PortInfo</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_fromPort</a> - The first
--   port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_cidrs</a> - The IPv4 address,
--   or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that are allowed to
--   connect to an instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   Examples:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To allow the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt> or <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To allow the IP addresses <tt>192.0.2.0</tt> to
--   <tt>192.0.2.255</tt>, specify <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_protocol</a> - The IP
--   protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrListAliases:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_cidrListAliases</a>
--   - An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Cidrs:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_ipv6Cidrs</a> - The IPv6
--   address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance through
--   IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_toPort</a> - The last port
--   in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
newPortInfo :: PortInfo

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
portInfo_fromPort :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe Int)

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   Examples:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To allow the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt> or <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To allow the IP addresses <tt>192.0.2.0</tt> to
--   <tt>192.0.2.255</tt>, specify <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
portInfo_cidrs :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
portInfo_protocol :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe NetworkProtocol)

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
portInfo_cidrListAliases :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
portInfo_ipv6Cidrs :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
portInfo_toPort :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe Int)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfo.PortInfo
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfo.PortInfo
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfo.PortInfo
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfo.PortInfo
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfo.PortInfo
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfo.PortInfo
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfo.PortInfo


module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType
newtype PortInfoSourceType
PortInfoSourceType' :: Text -> PortInfoSourceType
[fromPortInfoSourceType] :: PortInfoSourceType -> Text
pattern PortInfoSourceType_CLOSED :: PortInfoSourceType
pattern PortInfoSourceType_DEFAULT :: PortInfoSourceType
pattern PortInfoSourceType_INSTANCE :: PortInfoSourceType
pattern PortInfoSourceType_NONE :: PortInfoSourceType
instance Network.AWS.Data.XML.ToXML Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Network.AWS.Data.XML.FromXML Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSONKey Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSONKey Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeader Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Network.AWS.Data.Log.ToLog Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Network.AWS.Data.ByteString.ToByteString Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Network.AWS.Data.Text.ToText Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Network.AWS.Data.Text.FromText Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Classes.Ord Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType


module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry

-- | Describes the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud instance and related
--   resources to be created using the <tt>create cloud formation
--   stack</tt> operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceEntry</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceEntry
InstanceEntry' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> PortInfoSourceType -> Text -> InstanceEntry

-- | A launch script you can create that configures a server with
--   additional user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get
--   -y update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
[$sel:userData:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
[$sel:sourceName:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Text

-- | The instance type (e.g., <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
[$sel:instanceType:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Text

-- | The port configuration to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
[$sel:portInfoSource:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> PortInfoSourceType

-- | The Availability Zone for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
[$sel:availabilityZone:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceEntry</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:userData:InstanceEntry'</a>, <a>instanceEntry_userData</a> - A
--   launch script you can create that configures a server with additional
--   user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get -y
--   update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceName:InstanceEntry'</a>, <a>instanceEntry_sourceName</a>
--   - The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceType:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_instanceType</a> - The instance type (e.g.,
--   <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portInfoSource:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_portInfoSource</a> - The port configuration to use
--   for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_availabilityZone</a> - The Availability Zone for the
--   new Amazon EC2 instance.
newInstanceEntry :: Text -> Text -> PortInfoSourceType -> Text -> InstanceEntry

-- | A launch script you can create that configures a server with
--   additional user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get
--   -y update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
instanceEntry_userData :: Lens' InstanceEntry (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
instanceEntry_sourceName :: Lens' InstanceEntry Text

-- | The instance type (e.g., <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
instanceEntry_instanceType :: Lens' InstanceEntry Text

-- | The port configuration to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
instanceEntry_portInfoSource :: Lens' InstanceEntry PortInfoSourceType

-- | The Availability Zone for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
instanceEntry_availabilityZone :: Lens' InstanceEntry Text
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry


module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState
newtype PortState
PortState' :: Text -> PortState
[fromPortState] :: PortState -> Text
pattern PortState_Closed :: PortState
pattern PortState_Open :: PortState
instance Network.AWS.Data.XML.ToXML Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Network.AWS.Data.XML.FromXML Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSONKey Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSONKey Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeader Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Network.AWS.Data.Log.ToLog Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Network.AWS.Data.ByteString.ToByteString Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Network.AWS.Data.Text.ToText Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Network.AWS.Data.Text.FromText Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Classes.Ord Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState


module Network.AWS.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortState

-- | Describes open ports on an instance, the IP addresses allowed to
--   connect to the instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstancePortState</a> smart constructor.
data InstancePortState
InstancePortState' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe PortState -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Int -> InstancePortState

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:fromPort:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe Int

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:cidrs:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Specifies whether the instance port is <tt>open</tt> or
--   <tt>closed</tt>.
--   
--   The port state for Lightsail instances is always <tt>open</tt>.
[$sel:state:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe PortState

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:protocol:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe NetworkProtocol

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
[$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:toPort:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe Int

-- | Create a value of <a>InstancePortState</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_fromPort</a> - The first port in a range of open
--   ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_cidrs</a> -
--   The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_state</a> -
--   Specifies whether the instance port is <tt>open</tt> or
--   <tt>closed</tt>.
--   
--   The port state for Lightsail instances is always <tt>open</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_protocol</a> - The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
