exportSnapshotRecordSourceInfo_instanceSnapshotInfo :: Lens' ExportSnapshotRecordSourceInfo (Maybe InstanceSnapshotInfo)

-- | The name of the snapshot's source instance or disk.
exportSnapshotRecordSourceInfo_fromResourceName :: Lens' ExportSnapshotRecordSourceInfo (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes the request headers that a Lightsail distribution bases
--   caching on.
--   
--   For the headers that you specify, your distribution caches separate
--   versions of the specified content based on the header values in viewer
--   requests. For example, suppose viewer requests for <tt>logo.jpg</tt>
--   contain a custom <tt>product</tt> header that has a value of either
--   <tt>acme</tt> or <tt>apex</tt>, and you configure your distribution to
--   cache your content based on values in the <tt>product</tt> header.
--   Your distribution forwards the <tt>product</tt> header to the origin
--   and caches the response from the origin once for each header value.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newHeaderObject</a> smart constructor.
data HeaderObject
HeaderObject' :: Maybe [HeaderEnum] -> Maybe ForwardValues -> HeaderObject

-- | The specific headers to forward to your distribution's origin.
[$sel:headersAllowList:HeaderObject'] :: HeaderObject -> Maybe [HeaderEnum]

-- | The headers that you want your distribution to forward to your origin
--   and base caching on.
--   
--   You can configure your distribution to do one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>all</tt></b> - Forward all headers to your origin.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>none</tt></b> - Forward only the default headers.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>allow-list</tt></b> - Forward only the headers you specify
--   using the <tt>headersAllowList</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:option:HeaderObject'] :: HeaderObject -> Maybe ForwardValues

-- | Create a value of <a>HeaderObject</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:headersAllowList:HeaderObject'</a>,
--   <a>headerObject_headersAllowList</a> - The specific headers to forward
--   to your distribution's origin.
--   
--   <a>$sel:option:HeaderObject'</a>, <a>headerObject_option</a> - The
--   headers that you want your distribution to forward to your origin and
--   base caching on.
--   
--   You can configure your distribution to do one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>all</tt></b> - Forward all headers to your origin.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>none</tt></b> - Forward only the default headers.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>allow-list</tt></b> - Forward only the headers you specify
--   using the <tt>headersAllowList</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
newHeaderObject :: HeaderObject

-- | The specific headers to forward to your distribution's origin.
headerObject_headersAllowList :: Lens' HeaderObject (Maybe [HeaderEnum])

-- | The headers that you want your distribution to forward to your origin
--   and base caching on.
--   
--   You can configure your distribution to do one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>all</tt></b> - Forward all headers to your origin.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>none</tt></b> - Forward only the default headers.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>allow-list</tt></b> - Forward only the headers you specify
--   using the <tt>headersAllowList</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
headerObject_option :: Lens' HeaderObject (Maybe ForwardValues)

-- | Describes the public SSH host keys or the RDP certificate.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newHostKeyAttributes</a> smart constructor.
data HostKeyAttributes
HostKeyAttributes' :: Maybe POSIX -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> HostKeyAttributes

-- | The returned RDP certificate is not valid after this point in time.
--   
--   This value is listed only for RDP certificates.
[$sel:notValidAfter:HostKeyAttributes'] :: HostKeyAttributes -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The returned RDP certificate is valid after this point in time.
--   
--   This value is listed only for RDP certificates.
[$sel:notValidBefore:HostKeyAttributes'] :: HostKeyAttributes -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The SHA-1 fingerprint of the returned SSH host key or RDP certificate.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-1 SSH
--   fingerprint:<pre>SHA1:1CHH6FaAaXjtFOsR/t83vf91SR0</pre></li>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-1 RDP
--   fingerprint:<pre>af:34:51:fe:09:f0:e0:da:b8:4e:56:ca:60:c2:10:ff:38:06:db:45</pre></li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:fingerprintSHA1:HostKeyAttributes'] :: HostKeyAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | The public SSH host key or the RDP certificate.
[$sel:publicKey:HostKeyAttributes'] :: HostKeyAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | The SSH host key algorithm or the RDP certificate format.
--   
--   For SSH host keys, the algorithm may be <tt>ssh-rsa</tt>,
--   <tt>ecdsa-sha2-nistp256</tt>, <tt>ssh-ed25519</tt>, etc. For RDP
--   certificates, the algorithm is always <tt>x509-cert</tt>.
[$sel:algorithm:HostKeyAttributes'] :: HostKeyAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | The time that the SSH host key or RDP certificate was recorded by
--   Lightsail.
[$sel:witnessedAt:HostKeyAttributes'] :: HostKeyAttributes -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The SHA-256 fingerprint of the returned SSH host key or RDP
--   certificate.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-256 SSH
--   fingerprint:<pre>SHA256:KTsMnRBh1IhD17HpdfsbzeGA4jOijm5tyXsMjKVbB8o</pre></li>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-256 RDP
--   fingerprint:<pre>03:9b:36:9f:4b:de:4e:61:70:fc:7c:c9:78:e7:d2:1a:1c:25:a8:0c:91:f6:7c:e4:d6:a0:85:c8:b4:53:99:68</pre></li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:fingerprintSHA256:HostKeyAttributes'] :: HostKeyAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>HostKeyAttributes</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:notValidAfter:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_notValidAfter</a> - The returned RDP certificate
--   is not valid after this point in time.
--   
--   This value is listed only for RDP certificates.
--   
--   <a>$sel:notValidBefore:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_notValidBefore</a> - The returned RDP certificate
--   is valid after this point in time.
--   
--   This value is listed only for RDP certificates.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fingerprintSHA1:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_fingerprintSHA1</a> - The SHA-1 fingerprint of
--   the returned SSH host key or RDP certificate.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-1 SSH
--   fingerprint:<pre>SHA1:1CHH6FaAaXjtFOsR/t83vf91SR0</pre></li>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-1 RDP
--   fingerprint:<pre>af:34:51:fe:09:f0:e0:da:b8:4e:56:ca:60:c2:10:ff:38:06:db:45</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicKey:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_publicKey</a> - The public SSH host key or the
--   RDP certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:algorithm:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_algorithm</a> - The SSH host key algorithm or the
--   RDP certificate format.
--   
--   For SSH host keys, the algorithm may be <tt>ssh-rsa</tt>,
--   <tt>ecdsa-sha2-nistp256</tt>, <tt>ssh-ed25519</tt>, etc. For RDP
--   certificates, the algorithm is always <tt>x509-cert</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:witnessedAt:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_witnessedAt</a> - The time that the SSH host key
--   or RDP certificate was recorded by Lightsail.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fingerprintSHA256:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_fingerprintSHA256</a> - The SHA-256 fingerprint
--   of the returned SSH host key or RDP certificate.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-256 SSH
--   fingerprint:<pre>SHA256:KTsMnRBh1IhD17HpdfsbzeGA4jOijm5tyXsMjKVbB8o</pre></li>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-256 RDP
--   fingerprint:<pre>03:9b:36:9f:4b:de:4e:61:70:fc:7c:c9:78:e7:d2:1a:1c:25:a8:0c:91:f6:7c:e4:d6:a0:85:c8:b4:53:99:68</pre></li>
--   </ul>
newHostKeyAttributes :: HostKeyAttributes

-- | The returned RDP certificate is not valid after this point in time.
--   
--   This value is listed only for RDP certificates.
hostKeyAttributes_notValidAfter :: Lens' HostKeyAttributes (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The returned RDP certificate is valid after this point in time.
--   
--   This value is listed only for RDP certificates.
hostKeyAttributes_notValidBefore :: Lens' HostKeyAttributes (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The SHA-1 fingerprint of the returned SSH host key or RDP certificate.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-1 SSH
--   fingerprint:<pre>SHA1:1CHH6FaAaXjtFOsR/t83vf91SR0</pre></li>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-1 RDP
--   fingerprint:<pre>af:34:51:fe:09:f0:e0:da:b8:4e:56:ca:60:c2:10:ff:38:06:db:45</pre></li>
--   </ul>

-- | The public SSH host key or the RDP certificate.
hostKeyAttributes_publicKey :: Lens' HostKeyAttributes (Maybe Text)

-- | The SSH host key algorithm or the RDP certificate format.
--   
--   For SSH host keys, the algorithm may be <tt>ssh-rsa</tt>,
--   <tt>ecdsa-sha2-nistp256</tt>, <tt>ssh-ed25519</tt>, etc. For RDP
--   certificates, the algorithm is always <tt>x509-cert</tt>.
hostKeyAttributes_algorithm :: Lens' HostKeyAttributes (Maybe Text)

--   Lightsail.
hostKeyAttributes_witnessedAt :: Lens' HostKeyAttributes (Maybe UTCTime)

--   </ul>
hostKeyAttributes_fingerprintSHA256 :: Lens' HostKeyAttributes (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes the origin resource of an Amazon Lightsail content delivery
--   network (CDN) distribution.
--   
--   An origin can be a Lightsail instance or load balancer. A distribution
--   pulls content from an origin, caches it, and serves it to viewers via
--   a worldwide network of edge servers.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInputOrigin</a> smart constructor.
data InputOrigin
InputOrigin' :: Maybe RegionName -> Maybe Text -> Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum -> InputOrigin

-- | The AWS Region name of the origin resource.
[$sel:regionName:InputOrigin'] :: InputOrigin -> Maybe RegionName

-- | The name of the origin resource.
[$sel:name:InputOrigin'] :: InputOrigin -> Maybe Text

-- | The protocol that your Amazon Lightsail distribution uses when
--   establishing a connection with your origin to pull content.
[$sel:protocolPolicy:InputOrigin'] :: InputOrigin -> Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum

-- | Create a value of <a>InputOrigin</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:regionName:InputOrigin'</a>, <a>inputOrigin_regionName</a> -
--   The AWS Region name of the origin resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:InputOrigin'</a>, <a>inputOrigin_name</a> - The name of
--   the origin resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocolPolicy:InputOrigin'</a>,
--   <a>inputOrigin_protocolPolicy</a> - The protocol that your Amazon
--   Lightsail distribution uses when establishing a connection with your
--   origin to pull content.
newInputOrigin :: InputOrigin

-- | The AWS Region name of the origin resource.
inputOrigin_regionName :: Lens' InputOrigin (Maybe RegionName)

-- | The name of the origin resource.
inputOrigin_name :: Lens' InputOrigin (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol that your Amazon Lightsail distribution uses when
--   establishing a connection with your origin to pull content.
inputOrigin_protocolPolicy :: Lens' InputOrigin (Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum)

-- | Describes an instance (a virtual private server).
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstance</a> smart constructor.
data Instance
Instance' :: Maybe InstanceState -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [AddOn] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe InstanceNetworking -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe InstanceHardware -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Tag] -> Instance

-- | The status code and the state (e.g., <tt>running</tt>) for the
--   instance.
[$sel:state:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe InstanceState

-- | The type of resource (usually <tt>Instance</tt>).
[$sel:resourceType:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe ResourceType

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>arn:aws:lightsail:us-east-2:123456789101:Instance/244ad76f-8aad-4741-809f-12345EXAMPLE</tt>).
[$sel:arn:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | The timestamp when the instance was created (e.g.,
--   <tt>1479734909.17</tt>) in Unix time format.
[$sel:createdAt:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The region name and Availability Zone where the instance is located.
[$sel:location:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe ResourceLocation

-- | The name of the SSH key being used to connect to the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>).
[$sel:sshKeyName:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | An array of objects representing the add-ons enabled on the instance.
[$sel:addOns:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe [AddOn]

-- | The user name for connecting to the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>ec2-user</tt>).
[$sel:username:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | Information about the public ports and monthly data transfer rates for
--   the instance.
[$sel:networking:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe InstanceNetworking

-- | The bundle for the instance (e.g., <tt>micro_1_0</tt>).
[$sel:bundleId:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | The name the user gave the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>Amazon_Linux-1GB-Ohio-1</tt>).
[$sel:name:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | The IP address type of the instance.
--   
--   The possible values are <tt>ipv4</tt> for IPv4 only, and
--   <tt>dualstack</tt> for IPv4 and IPv6.
[$sel:ipAddressType:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe IpAddressType

-- | The support code. Include this code in your email to support when you
--   have questions about an instance or another resource in Lightsail.
--   This code enables our support team to look up your Lightsail
--   information more easily.
[$sel:supportCode:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | The blueprint ID (e.g., <tt>os_amlinux_2016_03</tt>).
[$sel:blueprintId:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | The private IP address of the instance.
[$sel:privateIpAddress:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | The friendly name of the blueprint (e.g., <tt>Amazon Linux</tt>).
[$sel:blueprintName:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether this instance has a static IP
--   assigned to it.
[$sel:isStaticIp:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Bool

-- | The public IP address of the instance.
[$sel:publicIpAddress:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe Text

-- | The size of the vCPU and the amount of RAM for the instance.
[$sel:hardware:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe InstanceHardware

-- | The IPv6 addresses of the instance.
[$sel:ipv6Addresses:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The tag keys and optional values for the resource. For more
--   information about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:tags:Instance'] :: Instance -> Maybe [Tag]

-- | Create a value of <a>Instance</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_state</a> - The status code
--   and the state (e.g., <tt>running</tt>) for the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_resourceType</a> - The
--   type of resource (usually <tt>Instance</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_arn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>arn:aws:lightsail:us-east-2:123456789101:Instance/244ad76f-8aad-4741-809f-12345EXAMPLE</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_createdAt</a> - The
--   timestamp when the instance was created (e.g., <tt>1479734909.17</tt>)
--   in Unix time format.
--   
--   <a>$sel:location:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_location</a> - The region
--   name and Availability Zone where the instance is located.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sshKeyName:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_sshKeyName</a> - The
--   name of the SSH key being used to connect to the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:addOns:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_addOns</a> - An array of
--   objects representing the add-ons enabled on the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_username</a> - The user
--   name for connecting to the instance (e.g., <tt>ec2-user</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:networking:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_networking</a> -
--   Information about the public ports and monthly data transfer rates for
--   the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bundleId:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_bundleId</a> - The bundle
--   for the instance (e.g., <tt>micro_1_0</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_name</a> - The name the user
--   gave the instance (e.g., <tt>Amazon_Linux-1GB-Ohio-1</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_ipAddressType</a> -
--   The IP address type of the instance.
--   
--   The possible values are <tt>ipv4</tt> for IPv4 only, and
--   <tt>dualstack</tt> for IPv4 and IPv6.
--   
--   <a>$sel:supportCode:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_supportCode</a> - The
--   support code. Include this code in your email to support when you have
--   questions about an instance or another resource in Lightsail. This
--   code enables our support team to look up your Lightsail information
--   more easily.
--   
--   <a>$sel:blueprintId:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_blueprintId</a> - The
--   blueprint ID (e.g., <tt>os_amlinux_2016_03</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:privateIpAddress:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_privateIpAddress</a> - The private IP address of the
--   instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:blueprintName:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_blueprintName</a> -
--   The friendly name of the blueprint (e.g., <tt>Amazon Linux</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:isStaticIp:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_isStaticIp</a> - A
--   Boolean value indicating whether this instance has a static IP
--   assigned to it.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicIpAddress:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_publicIpAddress</a>
--   - The public IP address of the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hardware:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_hardware</a> - The size of
--   the vCPU and the amount of RAM for the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Addresses:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_ipv6Addresses</a> -
--   The IPv6 addresses of the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_tags</a> - The tag keys and
--   optional values for the resource. For more information about tags in
--   Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
newInstance :: Instance

-- | The status code and the state (e.g., <tt>running</tt>) for the
--   instance.
instance_state :: Lens' Instance (Maybe InstanceState)

-- | The type of resource (usually <tt>Instance</tt>).
instance_resourceType :: Lens' Instance (Maybe ResourceType)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>arn:aws:lightsail:us-east-2:123456789101:Instance/244ad76f-8aad-4741-809f-12345EXAMPLE</tt>).
instance_arn :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | The timestamp when the instance was created (e.g.,
--   <tt>1479734909.17</tt>) in Unix time format.
instance_createdAt :: Lens' Instance (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The region name and Availability Zone where the instance is located.
instance_location :: Lens' Instance (Maybe ResourceLocation)

-- | The name of the SSH key being used to connect to the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>).
instance_sshKeyName :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | An array of objects representing the add-ons enabled on the instance.
instance_addOns :: Lens' Instance (Maybe [AddOn])

-- | The user name for connecting to the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>ec2-user</tt>).
instance_username :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | Information about the public ports and monthly data transfer rates for
--   the instance.
instance_networking :: Lens' Instance (Maybe InstanceNetworking)

-- | The bundle for the instance (e.g., <tt>micro_1_0</tt>).
instance_bundleId :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | The name the user gave the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>Amazon_Linux-1GB-Ohio-1</tt>).
instance_name :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP address type of the instance.
--   
--   The possible values are <tt>ipv4</tt> for IPv4 only, and
--   <tt>dualstack</tt> for IPv4 and IPv6.
instance_ipAddressType :: Lens' Instance (Maybe IpAddressType)

-- | The support code. Include this code in your email to support when you
--   have questions about an instance or another resource in Lightsail.
--   This code enables our support team to look up your Lightsail
--   information more easily.
instance_supportCode :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | The blueprint ID (e.g., <tt>os_amlinux_2016_03</tt>).
instance_blueprintId :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | The private IP address of the instance.
instance_privateIpAddress :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | The friendly name of the blueprint (e.g., <tt>Amazon Linux</tt>).
instance_blueprintName :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether this instance has a static IP
--   assigned to it.
instance_isStaticIp :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Bool)

-- | The public IP address of the instance.
instance_publicIpAddress :: Lens' Instance (Maybe Text)

-- | The size of the vCPU and the amount of RAM for the instance.
instance_hardware :: Lens' Instance (Maybe InstanceHardware)

-- | The IPv6 addresses of the instance.
instance_ipv6Addresses :: Lens' Instance (Maybe [Text])

-- | The tag keys and optional values for the resource. For more
--   information about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.
instance_tags :: Lens' Instance (Maybe [Tag])

-- | The parameters for gaining temporary access to one of your Amazon
--   Lightsail instances.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceAccessDetails</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceAccessDetails
InstanceAccessDetails' :: Maybe [HostKeyAttributes] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe InstanceAccessProtocol -> Maybe PasswordData -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> InstanceAccessDetails

-- | Describes the public SSH host keys or the RDP certificate.
[$sel:hostKeys:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe [HostKeyAttributes]

-- | For SSH access, the public key to use when accessing your instance For
--   OpenSSH clients (e.g., command line SSH), you should save this value
--   to <tt>tempkey-cert.pub</tt>.
[$sel:certKey:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | The public IP address of the Amazon Lightsail instance.
[$sel:ipAddress:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | For SSH access, the temporary private key. For OpenSSH clients (e.g.,
--   command line SSH), you should save this value to <tt>tempkey</tt>).
[$sel:privateKey:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | For SSH access, the date on which the temporary keys expire.
[$sel:expiresAt:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The user name to use when logging in to the Amazon Lightsail instance.
[$sel:username:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | The protocol for these Amazon Lightsail instance access details.
[$sel:protocol:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe InstanceAccessProtocol

-- | For a Windows Server-based instance, an object with the data you can
--   use to retrieve your password. This is only needed if
--   <tt>password</tt> is empty and the instance is not new (and therefore
--   the password is not ready yet). When you create an instance, it can
--   take up to 15 minutes for the instance to be ready.
[$sel:passwordData:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe PasswordData

-- | For RDP access, the password for your Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   Password will be an empty string if the password for your new instance
--   is not ready yet. When you create an instance, it can take up to 15
--   minutes for the instance to be ready.
--   
--   If you create an instance using any key pair other than the default
--   (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>), <tt>password</tt> will always be
--   an empty string.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original password value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
[$sel:password:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of this Amazon Lightsail instance.
[$sel:instanceName:InstanceAccessDetails'] :: InstanceAccessDetails -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceAccessDetails</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostKeys:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_hostKeys</a> - Describes the public SSH host
--   keys or the RDP certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:certKey:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_certKey</a> - For SSH access, the public key
--   to use when accessing your instance For OpenSSH clients (e.g., command
--   line SSH), you should save this value to <tt>tempkey-cert.pub</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddress:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_ipAddress</a> - The public IP address of the
--   Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:privateKey:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_privateKey</a> - For SSH access, the
--   temporary private key. For OpenSSH clients (e.g., command line SSH),
--   you should save this value to <tt>tempkey</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:expiresAt:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_expiresAt</a> - For SSH access, the date on
--   which the temporary keys expire.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_username</a> - The user name to use when
--   logging in to the Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_protocol</a> - The protocol for these Amazon
--   Lightsail instance access details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:passwordData:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_passwordData</a> - For a Windows Server-based
--   instance, an object with the data you can use to retrieve your
--   password. This is only needed if <tt>password</tt> is empty and the
--   instance is not new (and therefore the password is not ready yet).
--   When you create an instance, it can take up to 15 minutes for the
--   instance to be ready.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_password</a> - For RDP access, the password
--   for your Amazon Lightsail instance. Password will be an empty string
--   if the password for your new instance is not ready yet. When you
--   create an instance, it can take up to 15 minutes for the instance to
--   be ready.
--   
--   If you create an instance using any key pair other than the default
--   (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>), <tt>password</tt> will always be
--   an empty string.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original password value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceName:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_instanceName</a> - The name of this Amazon
--   Lightsail instance.
newInstanceAccessDetails :: InstanceAccessDetails

-- | Describes the public SSH host keys or the RDP certificate.
instanceAccessDetails_hostKeys :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe [HostKeyAttributes])

-- | For SSH access, the public key to use when accessing your instance For
--   OpenSSH clients (e.g., command line SSH), you should save this value
--   to <tt>tempkey-cert.pub</tt>.
instanceAccessDetails_certKey :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | The public IP address of the Amazon Lightsail instance.
instanceAccessDetails_ipAddress :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | For SSH access, the temporary private key. For OpenSSH clients (e.g.,
--   command line SSH), you should save this value to <tt>tempkey</tt>).
instanceAccessDetails_privateKey :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | For SSH access, the date on which the temporary keys expire.
instanceAccessDetails_expiresAt :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The user name to use when logging in to the Amazon Lightsail instance.
instanceAccessDetails_username :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol for these Amazon Lightsail instance access details.
instanceAccessDetails_protocol :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe InstanceAccessProtocol)

-- | For a Windows Server-based instance, an object with the data you can
--   use to retrieve your password. This is only needed if
--   <tt>password</tt> is empty and the instance is not new (and therefore
--   the password is not ready yet). When you create an instance, it can
--   take up to 15 minutes for the instance to be ready.
instanceAccessDetails_passwordData :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe PasswordData)

-- | For RDP access, the password for your Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   Password will be an empty string if the password for your new instance
--   is not ready yet. When you create an instance, it can take up to 15
--   minutes for the instance to be ready.
--   
--   If you create an instance using any key pair other than the default
--   (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>), <tt>password</tt> will always be
--   an empty string.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original password value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
instanceAccessDetails_password :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of this Amazon Lightsail instance.
instanceAccessDetails_instanceName :: Lens' InstanceAccessDetails (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud instance and related
--   resources to be created using the <tt>create cloud formation
--   stack</tt> operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceEntry</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceEntry
InstanceEntry' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> PortInfoSourceType -> Text -> InstanceEntry

-- | A launch script you can create that configures a server with
--   additional user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get
--   -y update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
[$sel:userData:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
[$sel:sourceName:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Text

-- | The instance type (e.g., <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
[$sel:instanceType:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Text

-- | The port configuration to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
[$sel:portInfoSource:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> PortInfoSourceType

-- | The Availability Zone for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
[$sel:availabilityZone:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceEntry</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:userData:InstanceEntry'</a>, <a>instanceEntry_userData</a> - A
--   launch script you can create that configures a server with additional
--   user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get -y
--   update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceName:InstanceEntry'</a>, <a>instanceEntry_sourceName</a>
--   - The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceType:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_instanceType</a> - The instance type (e.g.,
--   <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portInfoSource:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_portInfoSource</a> - The port configuration to use
--   for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_availabilityZone</a> - The Availability Zone for the
--   new Amazon EC2 instance.
newInstanceEntry :: Text -> Text -> PortInfoSourceType -> Text -> InstanceEntry

-- | A launch script you can create that configures a server with
--   additional user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get
--   -y update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
instanceEntry_userData :: Lens' InstanceEntry (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
instanceEntry_sourceName :: Lens' InstanceEntry Text

-- | The instance type (e.g., <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
instanceEntry_instanceType :: Lens' InstanceEntry Text

-- | The port configuration to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
instanceEntry_portInfoSource :: Lens' InstanceEntry PortInfoSourceType

-- | The Availability Zone for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
instanceEntry_availabilityZone :: Lens' InstanceEntry Text

-- | Describes the hardware for the instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceHardware</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceHardware
InstanceHardware' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Disk] -> Maybe Double -> InstanceHardware

-- | The number of vCPUs the instance has.
[$sel:cpuCount:InstanceHardware'] :: InstanceHardware -> Maybe Int

-- | The disks attached to the instance.
[$sel:disks:InstanceHardware'] :: InstanceHardware -> Maybe [Disk]

-- | The amount of RAM in GB on the instance (e.g., <tt>1.0</tt>).
[$sel:ramSizeInGb:InstanceHardware'] :: InstanceHardware -> Maybe Double

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceHardware</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:cpuCount:InstanceHardware'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHardware_cpuCount</a> - The number of vCPUs the instance
--   has.
--   
--   <a>$sel:disks:InstanceHardware'</a>, <a>instanceHardware_disks</a> -
--   The disks attached to the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ramSizeInGb:InstanceHardware'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHardware_ramSizeInGb</a> - The amount of RAM in GB on the
--   instance (e.g., <tt>1.0</tt>).
newInstanceHardware :: InstanceHardware

-- | The number of vCPUs the instance has.
instanceHardware_cpuCount :: Lens' InstanceHardware (Maybe Int)

-- | The disks attached to the instance.
instanceHardware_disks :: Lens' InstanceHardware (Maybe [Disk])

-- | The amount of RAM in GB on the instance (e.g., <tt>1.0</tt>).
instanceHardware_ramSizeInGb :: Lens' InstanceHardware (Maybe Double)

-- | Describes information about the health of the instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceHealthSummary</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceHealthSummary
InstanceHealthSummary' :: Maybe InstanceHealthState -> Maybe Text -> Maybe InstanceHealthReason -> InstanceHealthSummary

-- | Describes the overall instance health. Valid values are below.
[$sel:instanceHealth:InstanceHealthSummary'] :: InstanceHealthSummary -> Maybe InstanceHealthState

-- | The name of the Lightsail instance for which you are requesting health
--   check data.
[$sel:instanceName:InstanceHealthSummary'] :: InstanceHealthSummary -> Maybe Text

-- | More information about the instance health. If the
--   <tt>instanceHealth</tt> is <tt>healthy</tt>, then an
--   <tt>instanceHealthReason</tt> value is not provided.
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>initial</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.RegistrationInProgress</tt></b> - The target instance is
--   in the process of being registered with the load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.InitialHealthChecking</tt></b> - The Lightsail load
--   balancer is still sending the target instance the minimum number of
--   health checks required to determine its health status.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>unhealthy</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.ResponseCodeMismatch</tt></b> - The health checks
--   did not return an expected HTTP code.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.Timeout</tt></b> - The health check requests timed
--   out.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.FailedHealthChecks</tt></b> - The health checks
--   failed because the connection to the target instance timed out, the
--   target instance response was malformed, or the target instance failed
--   the health check for an unknown reason.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.InternalError</tt></b> - The health checks failed due to
--   an internal error.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>unused</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.NotRegistered</tt></b> - The target instance is
--   not registered with the target group.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.NotInUse</tt></b> - The target group is not used
--   by any load balancer, or the target instance is in an Availability
--   Zone that is not enabled for its load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.IpUnusable</tt></b> - The target IP address is
--   reserved for use by a Lightsail load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.InvalidState</tt></b> - The target is in the
--   stopped or terminated state.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>draining</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.DeregistrationInProgress</tt></b> - The target
--   instance is in the process of being deregistered and the
--   deregistration delay period has not expired.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:instanceHealthReason:InstanceHealthSummary'] :: InstanceHealthSummary -> Maybe InstanceHealthReason

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceHealthSummary</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceHealth:InstanceHealthSummary'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHealthSummary_instanceHealth</a> - Describes the overall
--   instance health. Valid values are below.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceName:InstanceHealthSummary'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHealthSummary_instanceName</a> - The name of the Lightsail
--   instance for which you are requesting health check data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceHealthReason:InstanceHealthSummary'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHealthSummary_instanceHealthReason</a> - More information
--   about the instance health. If the <tt>instanceHealth</tt> is
--   <tt>healthy</tt>, then an <tt>instanceHealthReason</tt> value is not
--   provided.
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>initial</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.RegistrationInProgress</tt></b> - The target instance is
--   in the process of being registered with the load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.InitialHealthChecking</tt></b> - The Lightsail load
--   balancer is still sending the target instance the minimum number of
--   health checks required to determine its health status.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>unhealthy</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.ResponseCodeMismatch</tt></b> - The health checks
--   did not return an expected HTTP code.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.Timeout</tt></b> - The health check requests timed
--   out.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.FailedHealthChecks</tt></b> - The health checks
--   failed because the connection to the target instance timed out, the
--   target instance response was malformed, or the target instance failed
--   the health check for an unknown reason.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.InternalError</tt></b> - The health checks failed due to
--   an internal error.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>unused</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.NotRegistered</tt></b> - The target instance is
--   not registered with the target group.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.NotInUse</tt></b> - The target group is not used
--   by any load balancer, or the target instance is in an Availability
--   Zone that is not enabled for its load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.IpUnusable</tt></b> - The target IP address is
--   reserved for use by a Lightsail load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.InvalidState</tt></b> - The target is in the
--   stopped or terminated state.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>draining</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.DeregistrationInProgress</tt></b> - The target
--   instance is in the process of being deregistered and the
--   deregistration delay period has not expired.</li>
--   </ul>
newInstanceHealthSummary :: InstanceHealthSummary

-- | Describes the overall instance health. Valid values are below.
instanceHealthSummary_instanceHealth :: Lens' InstanceHealthSummary (Maybe InstanceHealthState)

-- | The name of the Lightsail instance for which you are requesting health
--   check data.
instanceHealthSummary_instanceName :: Lens' InstanceHealthSummary (Maybe Text)

-- | More information about the instance health. If the
--   <tt>instanceHealth</tt> is <tt>healthy</tt>, then an
--   <tt>instanceHealthReason</tt> value is not provided.
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>initial</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.RegistrationInProgress</tt></b> - The target instance is
--   in the process of being registered with the load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.InitialHealthChecking</tt></b> - The Lightsail load
--   balancer is still sending the target instance the minimum number of
--   health checks required to determine its health status.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>unhealthy</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.ResponseCodeMismatch</tt></b> - The health checks
--   did not return an expected HTTP code.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.Timeout</tt></b> - The health check requests timed
--   out.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.FailedHealthChecks</tt></b> - The health checks
--   failed because the connection to the target instance timed out, the
--   target instance response was malformed, or the target instance failed
--   the health check for an unknown reason.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.InternalError</tt></b> - The health checks failed due to
--   an internal error.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>unused</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.NotRegistered</tt></b> - The target instance is
--   not registered with the target group.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.NotInUse</tt></b> - The target group is not used
--   by any load balancer, or the target instance is in an Availability
--   Zone that is not enabled for its load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.IpUnusable</tt></b> - The target IP address is
--   reserved for use by a Lightsail load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.InvalidState</tt></b> - The target is in the
--   stopped or terminated state.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>draining</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.DeregistrationInProgress</tt></b> - The target
--   instance is in the process of being deregistered and the
--   deregistration delay period has not expired.</li>
--   </ul>
instanceHealthSummary_instanceHealthReason :: Lens' InstanceHealthSummary (Maybe InstanceHealthReason)

-- | Describes monthly data transfer rates and port information for an
--   instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceNetworking</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceNetworking
InstanceNetworking' :: Maybe MonthlyTransfer -> Maybe [InstancePortInfo] -> InstanceNetworking

-- | The amount of data in GB allocated for monthly data transfers.
[$sel:monthlyTransfer:InstanceNetworking'] :: InstanceNetworking -> Maybe MonthlyTransfer

-- | An array of key-value pairs containing information about the ports on
--   the instance.
[$sel:ports:InstanceNetworking'] :: InstanceNetworking -> Maybe [InstancePortInfo]

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceNetworking</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:monthlyTransfer:InstanceNetworking'</a>,
--   <a>instanceNetworking_monthlyTransfer</a> - The amount of data in GB
--   allocated for monthly data transfers.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ports:InstanceNetworking'</a>, <a>instanceNetworking_ports</a>
--   - An array of key-value pairs containing information about the ports
--   on the instance.
newInstanceNetworking :: InstanceNetworking

-- | The amount of data in GB allocated for monthly data transfers.
instanceNetworking_monthlyTransfer :: Lens' InstanceNetworking (Maybe MonthlyTransfer)

-- | An array of key-value pairs containing information about the ports on
--   the instance.
instanceNetworking_ports :: Lens' InstanceNetworking (Maybe [InstancePortInfo])

-- | Describes information about ports for an Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstancePortInfo</a> smart constructor.
data InstancePortInfo
InstancePortInfo' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe AccessDirection -> Maybe PortAccessType -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> InstancePortInfo

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:fromPort:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe Int

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:cidrs:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The common name of the port information.
[$sel:commonName:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:protocol:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe NetworkProtocol

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
[$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The access direction (<tt>inbound</tt> or <tt>outbound</tt>).
--   
--   Lightsail currently supports only <tt>inbound</tt> access direction.
[$sel:accessDirection:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe AccessDirection

-- | The type of access (<tt>Public</tt> or <tt>Private</tt>).
[$sel:accessType:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe PortAccessType

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:toPort:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe Int

-- | The location from which access is allowed. For example, <tt>Anywhere
--   (0.0.0.0/0)</tt>, or <tt>Custom</tt> if a specific IP address or range
--   of IP addresses is allowed.
[$sel:accessFrom:InstancePortInfo'] :: InstancePortInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>InstancePortInfo</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_fromPort</a> - The first port in a range of open
--   ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:InstancePortInfo'</a>, <a>instancePortInfo_cidrs</a> -
--   The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:commonName:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_commonName</a> - The common name of the port
--   information.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_protocol</a> - The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_cidrListAliases</a> - An alias that defines access
--   for a preconfigured range of IP addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_ipv6Cidrs</a> - The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6
--   addresses (in CIDR notation) that are allowed to connect to an
--   instance through the ports, and the protocol. Only devices with an
--   IPv6 address can connect to an instance through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4
--   should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessDirection:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_accessDirection</a> - The access direction
--   (<tt>inbound</tt> or <tt>outbound</tt>).
--   
--   Lightsail currently supports only <tt>inbound</tt> access direction.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessType:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_accessType</a> - The type of access
--   (<tt>Public</tt> or <tt>Private</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:InstancePortInfo'</a>, <a>instancePortInfo_toPort</a> -
--   The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessFrom:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_accessFrom</a> - The location from which access is
--   allowed. For example, <tt>Anywhere (0.0.0.0/0)</tt>, or
--   <tt>Custom</tt> if a specific IP address or range of IP addresses is
--   allowed.
newInstancePortInfo :: InstancePortInfo

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
instancePortInfo_fromPort :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe Int)

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
instancePortInfo_cidrs :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The common name of the port information.
instancePortInfo_commonName :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
instancePortInfo_protocol :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe NetworkProtocol)

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
instancePortInfo_cidrListAliases :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
instancePortInfo_ipv6Cidrs :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The access direction (<tt>inbound</tt> or <tt>outbound</tt>).
--   
--   Lightsail currently supports only <tt>inbound</tt> access direction.
instancePortInfo_accessDirection :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe AccessDirection)

-- | The type of access (<tt>Public</tt> or <tt>Private</tt>).
instancePortInfo_accessType :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe PortAccessType)

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
instancePortInfo_toPort :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe Int)

-- | The location from which access is allowed. For example, <tt>Anywhere
--   (0.0.0.0/0)</tt>, or <tt>Custom</tt> if a specific IP address or range
--   of IP addresses is allowed.
instancePortInfo_accessFrom :: Lens' InstancePortInfo (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes open ports on an instance, the IP addresses allowed to
--   connect to the instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstancePortState</a> smart constructor.
data InstancePortState
InstancePortState' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe PortState -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Int -> InstancePortState

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:fromPort:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe Int

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:cidrs:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Specifies whether the instance port is <tt>open</tt> or
--   <tt>closed</tt>.
--   
--   The port state for Lightsail instances is always <tt>open</tt>.
[$sel:state:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe PortState

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:protocol:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe NetworkProtocol

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
[$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:toPort:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe Int

-- | Create a value of <a>InstancePortState</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_fromPort</a> - The first port in a range of open
--   ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_cidrs</a> -
--   The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_state</a> -
--   Specifies whether the instance port is <tt>open</tt> or
--   <tt>closed</tt>.
--   
--   The port state for Lightsail instances is always <tt>open</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_protocol</a> - The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_cidrListAliases</a> - An alias that defines
--   access for a preconfigured range of IP addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
